questions.text: Bones ossified at birth are all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Upper end of radius

Explanation:

At birth, certain bones already show ossification centers. These include:

• Lower end of femur — appears before birth (around 9th month of intrauterine life).

• Upper end of tibia — appears just before or at birth.

• Calcaneus — the primary ossification center appears during fetal life.

The upper end of the radius ossifies after birth (around 5 years of age). Hence, it is not ossified at birth.

questions.text: All of the following are examples of saddle joints except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Wrist joint

Explanation:

• Saddle joints (sellar joints) are biaxial synovial joints where both articular surfaces are concave and convex, fitting together like a rider on a saddle.

• Examples include:

o Sternoclavicular joint

o Calcaneocuboid joint

o Incudomalleolar joint

o First carpometacarpal joint (thumb)

The wrist joint (radiocarpal joint), however, is an ellipsoid (condyloid) joint, not a saddle joint.

questions.text: Which ligament transfers weight from the peripheral to the axial skeleton?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Coracoclavicular ligament

• The coracoclavicular ligament connects the clavicle (appendicular skeleton) to the coracoid process of the scapula (part of the axial skeleton connection via the clavicle).

• It acts as the main suspensory ligament of the upper limb, transmitting weight from the upper limb (peripheral skeleton) to the axial skeleton through the clavicle and sternoclavicular joint.

• It consists of two parts:

- Conoid ligament (medial and vertical)

- Trapezoid ligament (lateral and oblique)

questions.text: Which of the following is comprised of Dense Irregular Connective Tissue?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Dermis

Explanation:

• Dense Irregular Connective Tissue is characterized by collagen fibers arranged in multiple directions, providing strength and resistance to stress from various angles.

• The dermis, especially its reticular layer, is composed of dense irregular connective tissue, allowing the skin to withstand stretching and mechanical stress in different directions.

questions.text: What represents the marked area in the given histology of lymph node?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Mantle zone

Explanation:

• The mantle zone (also called the corona) is the darkly stained ring of small resting lymphocytes that surrounds the germinal center in a secondary lymphoid follicle.

• It represents B cells that have not been activated by antigen exposure.

• The germinal center inside the follicle contains activated, proliferating B lymphocytes (centroblasts and centrocytes), while the mantle zone contains naïve or resting B cells displaced outward by germinal center expansion.

questions.text:
Arrange the cells according to their positions from the basal layer towards the lumen in the seminiferous tubules.

1. Spermatogonia

2. Primary spermatocyte

3. Spermatid

4. Spermatozoa

5. Myoepithelial cell
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

5, 1, 2, 3, 4

The seminiferous tubules are the site of spermatogenesis, and their wall is organized in a well-defined order from outer (basal lamina) to inner (lumen):

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles are supplied by the Superior Gluteal Nerve?

1.  Gluteus medius

2.  Gluteus minimus

3.  Tensor fasciae latae

4.  Piriformis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

1, 2, 3

Explanation:

The Superior Gluteal Nerve arises from the dorsal divisions of the L4, L5, and S1 roots of the sacral plexus.

It exits the pelvis through the greater sciatic foramen above the piriformis muscle and supplies the following muscles:

Piriformis is not supplied by the superior gluteal nerve — it is supplied by the nerve to piriformis (from S1 and S2).

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman was undergoing cholecystectomy. During the procedure, the resident accidentally advanced the scissors along the superior border of the epiploic foramen, causing injury. Which of the following structures is likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Caudate lobe of liver

Explanation:

The epiploic foramen (foramen of Winslow) is a vertical slit about 3 cm long, located behind the free right border of the lesser omentum. It provides communication between the lesser sac (omental bursa) and the greater sac of the peritoneal cavity.

Hence, injury along the superior border of the epiploic foramen would likely damage the caudate lobe of the liver.

questions.text: What is the root value of the cremasteric reflex?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

L1, L2

The cremasteric reflex is mediated by the L1 and L2 spinal segments through the genitofemoral nerve.

Mechanism of the Reflex:

• Afferent limb: Femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve and ilioinguinal nerve — these carry sensory input from the skin of the medial thigh.

• Efferent limb: Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve — supplies the cremaster muscle, causing it to contract.

questions.text:
Identify the incorrectly matched pair of pharyngeal arch and its artery:

i. 1st arch – Maxillary artery

ii. 2nd arch – Hyoid and stapedial artery

iii. 3rd arch – Common carotid and proximal internal carotid artery

iv. 4th arch – Subclavian artery

v. 6th arch – Aorta on the left side
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

V

Explanation:

The 6th pharyngeal arch gives rise to:

• Left side: Left pulmonary artery and ductus arteriosus

• Right side: Right pulmonary artery

Hence, option (v) — stating that the 6th arch forms the aorta — is incorrect.

choices.text: Equal permeability to Na⁺ and K⁺
Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase and selective K⁺ leak

questions.text: Which of the following contributes most to the generation of the resting membrane potential in neurons?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

•  The resting membrane potential (RMP) of neurons (~ –70 mV) is primarily determined by the selective permeability of the membrane to K⁺ ions through leak channels.

•  Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase maintains the ionic gradients (high intracellular K⁺ and low intracellular Na⁺), which are essential for RMP, but the K⁺ leak predominates in setting its actual value.

•  The RMP is close to the equilibrium potential for K⁺ (Eₖ) as described by the Nernst equation.

questions.text: A newborn develops hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN) due to Rh incompatibility. Which maternal antibody is responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: (C) 

• IgG is the only immunoglobulin class that crosses the placenta, providing passive immunity to the fetus.

• In Rh incompatibility, an Rh-negative mother is exposed to Rh-positive fetal RBCs (usually during the first pregnancy or delivery).

• This exposure stimulates the mother’s immune system to produce anti-D IgG antibodies.

• In subsequent pregnancies, these IgG antibodies cross the placenta and attack fetal Rh-positive red blood cells, leading to hemolytic disease of the newborn (HDN).

questions.text: A patient with damage to Meissner’s corpuscles would most likely experience difficulty perceiving which of the following sensations?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Fine touch

• Meissner’s corpuscles are rapidly adapting mechanoreceptors located in glabrous (hairless) skin, such as fingertips, lips, and palms.

• They are responsible for detecting fine touch, light pressure, and texture changes.

• Damage to these corpuscles leads to impaired fine touch and tactile discrimination.

choices.text: Closure of aortic and pulmonary valves
Opening of mitral and tricuspid valves
Closure of mitral and tricuspid valves

questions.text: The first heart sound (S1) corresponds to which of the following cardiac events?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Closure of mitral and tricuspid valves

Explanation:

• The first heart sound (S1) is produced by the closure of the atrioventricular (AV) valves — mitral and tricuspid valves — at the beginning of ventricular systole.

• It marks the onset of ventricular contraction and the end of diastole.

• The sound intensity is primarily influenced by the rate of pressure rise in the ventricles and the valve position at the onset of systole.

choices.text: It is generated by smooth muscle
It determines the maximum frequency of contractions
It is absent in the colon

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the basal electrical rhythm (BER) in the gastrointestinal tract?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

It determines the maximum frequency of contractions

• The basal electrical rhythm (BER), also known as the slow wave potential, is generated by the interstitial cells of Cajal (ICC) — the pacemaker cells of the GI tract.

• BER sets the rhythmic depolarization pattern in smooth muscle but does not itself cause contraction.

• Contractions occur only when the BER depolarization reaches the threshold and action potentials are superimposed.

• Thus, BER determines the maximum possible frequency of contractions in each segment of the GI tract.

questions.text: During labored breathing in COPD, which of the following muscles contributes to active inspiration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Sternocleidomastoid

• During labored or forced inspiration (as in COPD), accessory inspiratory muscles are recruited to expand the thoracic cavity.

• These include the sternocleidomastoid and scalene muscles, which elevate the sternum and upper ribs.

• Internal intercostals, transversus abdominis, and rectus abdominis are expiratory muscles, active during forced expiration.

questions.text: Which segment of the nephron is responsible for actively transporting NaCl into the interstitium and is impermeable to water, contributing to medullary hypertonicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Thick ascending limb

• The thick ascending limb (TAL) of the loop of Henle plays a crucial role in urine concentration.

• It actively reabsorbs Na⁺, K⁺, and Cl⁻ via the Na⁺–K⁺–2Cl⁻ cotransporter (NKCC2).

• Importantly, it is impermeable to water, meaning that solute reabsorption without water movement makes the tubular fluid hypotonic while increasing medullary interstitial osmolarity.

• This property establishes the osmotic gradient essential for water reabsorption in the collecting ducts (counter-current multiplier system).

questions.text: During the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle, progesterone is responsible for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Endometrial secretory transformation

• The luteal phase follows ovulation and is dominated by progesterone secreted from the corpus luteum.

• Progesterone acts on the proliferative endometrium (previously built under estrogen influence) and transforms it into a secretory endometrium, rich in glands and nutrients—preparing it for possible implantation.

• It also thickens cervical mucus, making it less permeable to sperm, and inhibits uterine contractions.

questions.text: A 17-year-old phenotypic female has primary amenorrhea. She has sparse axillary hair and a blind-ending vagina. Karyotype is 46,XY. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome

• Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome (AIS) occurs in individuals with a 46,XY karyotype due to mutation in the androgen receptor gene, leading to end-organ resistance to androgens.

• Despite having testes that produce testosterone and anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH), tissues cannot respond to androgens → external female phenotype.

• AMH causes regression of Müllerian structures (uterus, upper vagina), resulting in a blind-ending vagina and absent uterus.

• Sparse axillary and pubic hair occurs due to lack of androgen action.

questions.text: On the accompanying graph, the shift from curve A to curve B could be caused by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Fetal hemoglobin (HbF)

• The O₂–hemoglobin dissociation curve depicts the relationship between PO₂ (partial pressure of oxygen) and hemoglobin saturation.

• A leftward shift (as seen from curve A → B) indicates an increased affinity of hemoglobin for oxygen, meaning hemoglobin binds oxygen more tightly and releases it less readily to tissues.

Causes of Left Shift (↑ O₂ Affinity):

• ↓ Temperature

• ↓ 2,3-DPG

• ↓ H⁺ (↑ pH, alkalosis)

• Presence of fetal hemoglobin (HbF)

• Carbon monoxide binding (COHb formation)

Fetal Hemoglobin (HbF):

• HbF has two γ-chains instead of β-chains, which bind 2,3-DPG less strongly than adult HbA.

• As a result, HbF holds O₂ more tightly, facilitating oxygen transfer from maternal to fetal blood across the placenta.

Why Other Options Are Incorrect:

• B. CO poisoning: Causes a left shift and reduces available O₂-binding sites → ↓ O₂-carrying capacity.

• C. Increased temperature and D. Increased 2,3-DPG: Both cause a rightward shift, promoting O₂ unloading in tissues.

questions.text: All of the following vitamin deficiencies will prevent thymine insertion in DNA except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

Vitamin E

Explanation:

• Thymine synthesis in DNA requires the conversion of deoxyuridine monophosphate (dUMP) to deoxythymidine monophosphate (dTMP).

• This reaction is catalyzed by thymidylate synthase, which needs methyl groups supplied by N⁵,N¹⁰-methylene tetrahydrofolate (THF) — a derivative of folate.

• Vitamin B12 (cobalamin) is required to regenerate active tetrahydrofolate from methyl-THF, while Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) is involved in one-carbon metabolism that supports folate function.

Thus, deficiencies of Folate, B12, or B6 impair DNA synthesis — particularly thymine incorporation — leading to megaloblastic changes.

Why Vitamin E Is the Exception:

• Vitamin E functions as a lipid-soluble antioxidant, protecting cell membranes from oxidative damage.

• It has no role in DNA synthesis or thymine incorporation, so its deficiency does not affect thymine insertion.

questions.text: A patient on primaquine therapy presents with hemolysis. The enzyme inhibited is present in which of the following pathways?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

HMP shunt

Explanation:

• Primaquine can cause oxidative stress in red blood cells, leading to hemolysis in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.

• G6PD is a key enzyme in the hexose monophosphate (HMP) shunt or pentose phosphate pathway.

• This pathway generates NADPH, which maintains reduced glutathione (GSH) — essential for protecting RBCs from oxidative damage.
When G6PD is deficient, NADPH levels fall, glutathione is depleted, and RBCs become vulnerable to oxidative injury, resulting in hemolysis after exposure to drugs like primaquine, sulfonamides, or nitrofurantoin.
Why Other Options Are Incorrect:

• (B) Gluconeogenesis: Synthesizes glucose from non-carbohydrate sources — not involved in NADPH generation.

• (C) Fatty acid synthesis: Uses NADPH but does not generate it; G6PD deficiency affects NADPH supply, not fatty acid synthesis directly.

• (D) Glycolysis: Produces ATP and pyruvate, not NADPH; unrelated to oxidative protection in RBCs.

questions.text: Which of the following two monosaccharides are constituents of lactulose?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Galactose and Fructose
Explanation:

• Lactulose is a synthetic disaccharide composed of galactose and fructose joined by a β-1,4-glycosidic linkage.

• It is not naturally occurring — it is formed by isomerization of lactose (galactose + glucose) during heat treatment.

Clinical Significance:

• Lactulose is used as:

- An osmotic laxative — it draws water into the colon to relieve constipation.

- A treatment for hepatic encephalopathy — by reducing intestinal ammonia absorption via acidification of colonic contents.

Why Other Options Are Incorrect:

• (A) Galactose and Glucose: These form lactose, not lactulose.

• (B) Glucose and Fructose: Form sucrose.

• (D) Fructose and Mannose: Not a naturally occurring disaccharide.

questions.text: Which of the following processes is mediated by CRISPR-Cas9 technology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Gene editing

Explanation:

• CRISPR-Cas9 stands for Clustered Regularly Interspaced Short Palindromic Repeats – CRISPR-associated protein 9.

• It is a genome editing tool derived from a bacterial defense mechanism that recognizes and cleaves invading viral DNA.

• The system uses a guide RNA (gRNA) that directs the Cas9 endonuclease to a specific DNA sequence, where Cas9 introduces a double-stranded break.

• The break is then repaired by the cell’s own DNA repair mechanisms, allowing for targeted gene modification (insertion, deletion, or replacement).

Why Others Are Incorrect:

• (B) DNA replication: Carried out by DNA polymerases, not CRISPR.

• (C) Post-translational modification: Involves protein processing (e.g., phosphorylation), not DNA editing.

• (D) Proteomics: Refers to large-scale study of proteins, unrelated to gene editing.

questions.text: Insulin-dependent entry of glucose is seen in –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Heart

Explanation:

• Insulin-dependent glucose uptake occurs in tissues that express the GLUT-4 transporter, which is insulin-sensitive.

• The main insulin-dependent tissues include:

- Skeletal muscle

- Cardiac muscle (heart)

- Adipose tissue

Why Other Options Are Incorrect:

• (A) Liver: Uses GLUT-2, which is insulin-independent and facilitates bidirectional glucose transport.

• (B) Brain: Uses GLUT-1 and GLUT-3, both insulin-independent and ensure constant glucose supply.

• (D) Kidney: Uses GLUT-2 (in proximal tubule) for reabsorption — also insulin-independent.

choices.text: Represents primarily cholesterol that is being removed from peripheral cells.
Binds to a receptor and diffuses across the cell membrane.
On accumulation in the cell inhibits replenishment of LDL receptors.
When enters a cell, suppresses activity of acyl-CoA:cholesterol acyltransferase (ACAT).

questions.text: Cholesterol present in LDL:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

On accumulation in the cell inhibits replenishment of LDL receptors.

Explanation:

• LDL (Low-Density Lipoprotein) delivers cholesterol from the liver to peripheral tissues.

• LDL binds to LDL receptors on cell membranes and is taken up by receptor-mediated endocytosis.

• Once inside the cell, free cholesterol is released.

• Increased intracellular cholesterol leads to:

1. Inhibition of HMG-CoA reductase → ↓ endogenous cholesterol synthesis.

2. Decreased synthesis of LDL receptors → ↓ further uptake of LDL.

3. Activation of ACAT → conversion of free cholesterol to cholesteryl esters for storage.

Why Other Options Are Incorrect:

• (A) LDL delivers cholesterol to cells, it does not remove it (that’s the function of HDL).

• (B) LDL does not diffuse across the membrane; uptake is via LDL receptor-mediated endocytosis.

• (D) Free cholesterol stimulates, not suppresses, ACAT activity to promote cholesterol ester formation for storage.

questions.text: Glutamine synthetase is a:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Ligase

Explanation:

• Glutamine synthetase catalyzes the ATP-dependent reaction:

Glutamate + NH₃ + ATP → Glutamine + ADP + Pi

• This reaction forms a new C–N bond using energy from ATP hydrolysis, a hallmark of ligase enzymes.

• Ligases catalyze bond formation (C–O, C–S, C–N, or C–C) with ATP cleavage.

Why Other Options Are Incorrect:

• (A) Isomerase: Catalyzes intramolecular rearrangements — no bond formation.

• (C) Lyase: Catalyzes bond cleavage without hydrolysis or oxidation, not bond formation.

• (D) Transferase: Transfers functional groups between molecules but does not form new bonds using ATP.

questions.text: Which one of the following amino acids is most likely to be found in the transmembrane region of a protein?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Leucine

• The transmembrane region of proteins is embedded within the hydrophobic lipid bilayer of cell membranes.

• Therefore, amino acids in these regions are typically nonpolar and hydrophobic.

• Leucine is a hydrophobic, aliphatic amino acid, commonly found in α-helical transmembrane segments.

Why Other Options Are Incorrect:

• (A) Lysine – Positively charged (basic), prefers aqueous or polar environments.

• (B) Arginine – Also positively charged and hydrophilic.

• (D) Aspartate – Negatively charged (acidic), found on protein surfaces interacting with water.

questions.text: Refsum’s disease is due to deficiency of which of the following enzyme?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Phytanic alpha oxidase

Explanation:

• Refsum’s disease is a peroxisomal disorder caused by a deficiency of the enzyme phytanic acid α-oxidase, which is responsible for the α-oxidation of phytanic acid (a branched-chain fatty acid derived from phytol).

• As a result, phytanic acid accumulates in tissues, especially in the nervous system, skin, and retina.

Why Other Options Are Incorrect:

• (A) Malonate dehydrogenase – Involved in the TCA cycle.

• (B) Thiophorase – Involved in ketone body utilization.

• (C) Succinate thiokinase – Catalyzes conversion of succinyl-CoA to succinate in the TCA cycle.

choices.text: Purines are adenine and guanine & pyrimidines are uracil and cytosine
Watson and Crick discovered structure in 1973
Deoxyribose–phosphate backbone with bases stacked inside

questions.text: True about DNA structure:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Deoxyribose–phosphate backbone with bases stacked inside

Explanation:

• DNA is a double-stranded right-handed helix (B-form DNA) described by Watson and Crick in 1953, not 1973.

• The sugar–phosphate backbone forms the outer framework, while the nitrogenous bases (A–T and G–C) are stacked inside the helix, stabilized by hydrogen bonds and base stacking interactions.

• Purines: Adenine (A) and Guanine (G)

• Pyrimidines: Cytosine (C) and Thymine (T) — Uracil (U) is found only in RNA.

• The left-handed form (Z-DNA) exists but is rare.
